explanations.summary: NO is a free radical gas produced on demand (not stored) that activates soluble guanylyl cyclase intracellularly.

whyCorrect.d: NO has an unpaired electron making it a free radical, which contributes to its short half-life (~5 seconds).
whyCorrect.e: NO activates soluble guanylyl cyclase (sGC), an intracellular enzyme that produces cGMP to cause vasodilation.

whyIncorrect.a: NO is NOT stored in vesicles - it's synthesized on demand by NOS and diffuses freely across membranes.
whyIncorrect.b: NO is a paracrine (not autocrine) molecule - produced by endothelium, acts on adjacent smooth muscle.
whyIncorrect.c: NO is also produced by neurons (nNOS), macrophages (iNOS), and other cells - not exclusively endothelium.
whyIncorrect.f: NO INHIBITS platelet aggregation - it prevents thrombosis, not promotes it.

explanations.summary: Histamine and bradykinin are inflammatory mediators that increase capillary permeability by causing endothelial cell contraction and gap formation.

whyCorrect.a: Histamine causes endothelial cell contraction, creating gaps between cells that increase permeability - key mediator of acute inflammation.
whyCorrect.c: Bradykinin similarly increases capillary permeability and is a potent inflammatory mediator released from kininogen.

whyIncorrect.b: Adenosine causes vasodilation but does NOT significantly affect capillary permeability.
whyIncorrect.d: CO2 causes local vasodilation through pH changes but doesn't increase capillary permeability.
whyIncorrect.e: Endothelin is a potent vasoconstrictor - it doesn't increase capillary permeability.
whyIncorrect.f: NO causes vasodilation but does NOT increase capillary permeability - it actually helps maintain endothelial integrity.

explanations.topicReference: Topic 43: Capillary Exchange; Topic 46: Inflammatory Hyperemia

explanations.summary: Mean arterial pressure is the most tightly regulated hemodynamic parameter, maintained within narrow limits by baroreceptor reflexes.

whyCorrect.b: MAP is homeostatically regulated within ~90-100 mmHg. The baroreceptor reflex constantly adjusts CO and TPR to maintain stable MAP despite varying demands.

whyIncorrect.a: Cardiac output varies dramatically (5 L/min at rest to 25+ L/min during exercise) - highly variable.
whyIncorrect.c: Heart rate changes substantially (60-180+ bpm) with activity, emotions, and reflexes.
whyIncorrect.d: TPR changes significantly to redistribute blood flow to active organs and regulate MAP.

explanations.topicReference: Topic 42: Arterial Blood Pressure; Topic 47: Neural Regulation

explanations.summary: The carotid sinus baroreceptor reflex operates continuously at normal blood pressures to maintain hemodynamic stability.

whyCorrect.c: Carotid sinus baroreceptors are tonically active at normal BP (80-150 mmHg range), continuously modulating sympathetic and parasympathetic outflow.

whyIncorrect.a: Peripheral chemoreceptors primarily respond to hypoxia (PaO2 <60 mmHg) - not active at normal oxygen levels.
whyIncorrect.b: Central chemoreceptors respond to CO2/pH changes but are not a circulatory 'depressor' reflex - they cause pressor responses.
whyIncorrect.d: Cushing reflex only occurs during severe brain ischemia (elevated ICP) - an emergency response, not physiological.

explanations.summary: Skin vessels have minimal basal tone and rely primarily on sympathetic neurogenic tone for blood flow regulation.

whyCorrect.c: Skin has very LOW basal (myogenic) tone - its vessels are primarily controlled by sympathetic nerves for thermoregulation, not autoregulation.

whyIncorrect.a: Heart has strong basal tone and excellent autoregulation to maintain coronary flow across varying perfusion pressures.
whyIncorrect.b: Kidney has substantial basal tone with strong autoregulation to maintain stable GFR despite BP changes.
whyIncorrect.d: Brain has considerable basal tone with robust autoregulation to protect cerebral perfusion (50-150 mmHg range).

explanations.summary: Pulse pressure is the difference between systolic and diastolic pressures, and it diminishes as blood flows through arterioles due to resistance.

whyCorrect.b: Pulse pressure = systolic - diastolic pressure (e.g., 120 - 80 = 40 mmHg). This is the definition.
whyCorrect.d: Pulse pressure declines in arterioles because the high resistance dampens pulsatile flow, converting it to more steady flow.

whyIncorrect.a: DECREASED compliance (stiffer vessels) INCREASES pulse pressure - as in elderly patients with arteriosclerosis.
whyIncorrect.c: Capillaries have NO pulse pressure - the pulsatile component is completely dampened by arteriolar resistance.

explanations.topicReference: Topic 42: Arterial Blood Pressure and Pulse Pressure

explanations.summary: Basal tone is the intrinsic myogenic tone that remains after removing all neural and humoral influences - measured after denervation.

whyCorrect.c: Basal tone can only be determined after denervation, which removes the neurogenic component. What remains is the intrinsic myogenic tone.

whyIncorrect.a: Cerebral vessels DO have basal tone - they have excellent myogenic autoregulation.
whyIncorrect.b: Basal tone varies significantly between organs - brain, heart, kidney have high basal tone; skin has low basal tone.
whyIncorrect.d: Basal tone ≠ neurogenic tone. Resting tone = basal (myogenic) + neurogenic. They are distinct components.

explanations.summary: Mean pulmonary artery pressure is approximately 15 mmHg (range 10-20), much lower than systemic circulation.

whyCorrect.b: Mean PAP ≈ 15 mmHg (normal range 10-20 mmHg). Pulmonary circulation is a low-pressure, low-resistance system.

whyIncorrect.a: 8 mmHg is too low - this is closer to pulmonary capillary wedge pressure or left atrial pressure.
whyIncorrect.c: 100 mmHg is the mean systemic arterial pressure - way too high for pulmonary circulation.
whyIncorrect.d: 25 mmHg is the systolic pulmonary artery pressure, not the mean.
whyIncorrect.e: 60 mmHg would indicate severe pulmonary hypertension.

explanations.summary: Subendocardial blood flow occurs predominantly during diastole because systolic compression occludes intramural vessels.

whyCorrect.d: During systole, ventricular contraction compresses subendocardial vessels (extravascular compression), so blood flow occurs mainly during diastole when the muscle relaxes.

whyIncorrect.a: Blood flow is NOT equal - it's predominantly diastolic due to systolic compression.
whyIncorrect.b: The subendocardium IS vascularized by coronary arteries penetrating from epicardium - it's not avascular.
whyIncorrect.c: The opposite is true - subendocardial flow is REDUCED during systole due to mechanical compression.

explanations.summary: Total lymph flow in adults is approximately 1-2 ml/min (or 2-4 liters/day), returning filtered fluid and proteins to circulation.

whyCorrect.f: Lymph flow ≈ 1-2 ml/min (about 2-4 L/day). This returns approximately 10% of capillary filtrate back to the circulation.

whyIncorrect.a: 1-2 µL/min is far too low - this would be negligible.
whyIncorrect.c: 1-2 µL/hour is extremely low - practically no flow.
whyIncorrect.d: 1-2 ml/sec = 60-120 ml/min - too high, this would exceed capillary filtration.
whyIncorrect.e: 1-2 ml/hour is too low - only 24-48 ml/day.

explanations.summary: The critical function of lymphatics is removing proteins from interstitial fluid - proteins cannot return through capillaries.

whyCorrect.d: Proteins that leak from capillaries cannot return through the capillary wall. Lymphatics are the ONLY route for protein return to circulation, preventing edema.

whyIncorrect.a: Lymphatics transport absorbed lipids FROM intestine TO circulation, not to tissues generally.
whyIncorrect.b: Proteins are delivered to tissues via blood capillaries, not lymphatics.
whyIncorrect.c: Lymphocytes travel through lymphatics but delivering them is not the PRIMARY function.
whyIncorrect.e: Metabolites like lactate return via venous blood, not lymphatics.

explanations.summary: Arterial chemoreceptor stimulation and the cold pressor test both increase sympathetic outflow, causing vasoconstriction and increased TPR.

whyCorrect.e: Chemoreceptor stimulation (hypoxia, hypercapnia) triggers sympathetic activation causing widespread vasoconstriction and increased TPR.
whyCorrect.f: Cold pressor test (ice water immersion) activates cutaneous pain/cold receptors → sympathetic discharge → vasoconstriction → increased TPR.

whyIncorrect.a: Bezold-Jarisch reflex causes bradycardia, hypotension, and DECREASED TPR (a depressor reflex).
whyIncorrect.b: Baroreceptor activation inhibits sympathetic outflow → vasodilation → DECREASED TPR.
whyIncorrect.c: Parasympathetic inhibition affects heart rate but has minimal effect on TPR (veins/arterioles lack significant parasympathetic innervation).
whyIncorrect.d: β2-receptor stimulation causes vasodilation → DECREASED TPR (e.g., in skeletal muscle).

explanations.summary: According to Poiseuille's law, resistance is inversely proportional to r⁴ and can be expressed as inversely proportional to flow (R = ΔP/Q).

whyCorrect.a: Poiseuille: R = 8ηL/πr⁴. Resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of radius - small changes in radius dramatically affect resistance.
whyCorrect.d: R = ΔP/Q, therefore R is inversely proportional to flow when pressure gradient is constant.

whyIncorrect.b: Resistance is independent of pressure gradient - R = 8ηL/πr⁴ contains no pressure term.
whyIncorrect.c: Resistance is DIRECTLY proportional to viscosity (η is in the numerator).
whyIncorrect.e: Resistance is DIRECTLY proportional to length (L is in the numerator).

explanations.summary: Hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction (Euler-Liljestrand reflex) is unique to the lungs - hypoxia causes vasoconstriction to optimize V/Q matching.

whyCorrect.d: Pulmonary vessels uniquely CONSTRICT in response to hypoxia (HPV). This diverts blood away from poorly ventilated alveoli to optimize gas exchange.

whyIncorrect.a: Coronary vessels DILATE in response to hypoxia - metabolic vasodilation to increase oxygen delivery.
whyIncorrect.b: Cerebral vessels DILATE in response to hypoxia - to maintain brain oxygen supply.
whyIncorrect.c: Skeletal muscle vessels DILATE in response to hypoxia - metabolic hyperemia during exercise.

explanations.summary: The Frank-Starling mechanism ensures beat-to-beat matching of stroke volume to venous return through length-dependent changes in contractility.

whyCorrect.c: Frank-Starling law: increased preload (venous return) stretches cardiac muscle → increased force of contraction → matched stroke volume. This is intrinsic and beat-by-beat.

whyIncorrect.a: Vagal negative dromotropic effect slows conduction - doesn't match SV to venous return.
whyIncorrect.b: Sympathetic positive inotropy is slower (seconds) and not beat-by-beat matching.
whyIncorrect.d: Extracardiac mechanisms (hormones, reflexes) are slower and don't provide beat-by-beat matching.
whyIncorrect.e: Vagal negative inotropy (atria only) doesn't match ventricular output to venous return.

explanations.summary: The CNS ischemic response (Cushing reflex) is triggered by chemosensitive neurons in the ventral medulla responding to local hypoxia/hypercapnia.

whyCorrect.b: Central chemoreceptors in the ventral medulla detect brain ischemia (↑CO2, ↓pH, ↓O2) and trigger massive sympathetic discharge - the CNS ischemic response.

whyIncorrect.a: Carotid sinus contains baroreceptors (pressure sensors), not chemoreceptors for ischemic response.
whyIncorrect.c: Adrenal medulla releases catecholamines but is not a chemoreceptor location.
whyIncorrect.d: Right atrium contains volume receptors, not chemoreceptors.
whyIncorrect.e: Carotid bodies are peripheral chemoreceptors for arterial blood gases - separate from CNS ischemic response.

explanations.summary: Veins lack significant parasympathetic innervation - venous capacity is controlled by sympathetic nerves, posture, and other factors.

whyCorrect.d: Veins have NO significant parasympathetic innervation. Venous tone is controlled almost exclusively by sympathetic nerves.

whyIncorrect.a: Sympathetic nerves directly innervate veins and cause venoconstriction, affecting capacity.
whyIncorrect.b: Posture dramatically affects venous capacity through hydrostatic pressure effects.
whyIncorrect.c: Precapillary sphincter contraction affects upstream pressure and venous filling.
whyIncorrect.e: Right ventricular function affects venous pressure and thus venous volume/capacity.

explanations.summary: Veins have the highest compliance (ΔV/ΔP), holding ~70% of blood volume and serving as capacitance vessels.

whyCorrect.c: Veins have compliance ~20x higher than arteries. They're thin-walled, distensible capacitance vessels holding 60-70% of blood volume.

whyIncorrect.a: Muscular arteries have thick walls with smooth muscle - relatively low compliance.
whyIncorrect.b: Capillaries have very low compliance - minimal volume change with pressure.
whyIncorrect.d: Elastic arteries (aorta) have moderate compliance for Windkessel function but far less than veins.
